in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: Thesis
Phone Calls and Video Calls
We independently worked on our senior essays and never met as a "class" -- not sure why we're reviewing this course
Asynchronous assignments due for the History year-long senior essay.
This was a senior thesis independent study class.
Worked with my thesis advisor on my thesis. No specific class time.
research done at your own time
It was mostly on my own with semi-frequent Zoom meetings with my advisor.
One a week virtual meeting with Professor
Senior Essay
Independent work study, with occasional one-on-one check-ins with my advisor!
Sporadic meetings with thesis advisor
Research
No course meetings, thesis seminar
Met with advisor
Senior Essay - independent project
Meetings every few weeks
Independent research: Zoom and in-person one-on-one meetings with supervisor
All online.
The fall half of the two-term senior essay was held virtually over zoom, where students would meet with their advisor when they saw fit.
Senior thesis  one on one meetings with adviser
More of a freeform structure. There are not any specified weekly meetings, but you are free to set up meetings with your senior essay advisor whenever you want to.
Senior essay through phone calls and zoom
Regular check-ins with my advisor and independent study
It was the senior thesis so we met virtually over zoom to talk!
Comprised of regular meetings with senior thesis advisor, who is a Professor of History.
I participated in this class only through messages received on Canvas.
Individual work with check-ins with a professor to stay on top of scheduling
No formal course, just meetings with my thesis advisor

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Where to find resources and materials, where to begin research, how to create an argument
I gained skills in research, synthesis, writing, and time management
Research skills and progress for long-term, larger research projects.
How to conduct Archival research
Research skills
I was able to explore my thesis topic in-depth and learn how to conduct independent research with minimal guidance.
Research skills, writing
learned about the important components that go into a history thesis
I learned about how to do research more efficiently
Everything 1975 public corporations
I was able to think through my senior essay, and was guided by various aids to my writing such as the Prospectus and Primary Source Analysis.
History research and writing: This course is a great chance to focus on a particular part of history that interests you and to work with a leading professor in that field.
I have developed immensely as a researcher and writer over this term thanks to Professor Gitlin. I am very grateful yo have his support and mentorship during this difficult semester.
This class has taught me how to research for a long senior thesis. I have begun by coming up with a topic and conducting primary research for that topic.
How to research
Research skills

I learned a great deal about the beginning stages of a substantial historical research project. In my advising group, we spent most of our time discussing the best methods for selecting primary and secondary source material, as well as formulating an effective historical question.

I strengthened my skills in self-motivated research, primary source analysis, and ensuring the originality of a historical argument. Required both short-term and long-term planning, and an adherence to deadlines set by the history department. I learned a lot about the nature of independent study, and how to make use of the resources and people available to help you.
I learned the basic steps to writing the Senior Essay along with how to access library archives.

Working with my advisor has helped me develop effective strategies for doing research for my thesis, identify good sources and people to talk to, and overall has helped me to start the writing process. Having deadlines has helped me to split up the work into more attainable goals and make a long-term research project more manageable.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Professor Stern was incredibly supportive throughout the thesis writing process and continues to be!
N/A

Something between a primary source analysis and 10 pages - perhaps an outline? It was very difficult to write 10 pages without an outline and have it actually be useful. I likely will scrap every bit of it.
Thank you very much for extending the 10 page deadline. This allowed students to put together more thoughtful drafts and took a lot of the pressure off.
None
Strengths: Encourages students to stay ahead of the senior essay schedule

Fabian is very helpful, so I would definitely count him as a strength. He was flexible but kept me on track to meet the deadlines, and he gave good advice.

Honestly, while I understand the need for deadlines, I didn't find the assignments very helpful for actually propelling me forward in my thesis planning. I hear from a lot of History students, this year and past years, that they can get through the fall semester without doing much work at all on their thesis, and I definitely found that to be true for me as well. I wrote the several short papers, I met the deadlines, but I would have found a different structure more helpful. Perhaps future students could instead have weekly deadlines for which they have to read, say, 1 book and 1 article and write summaries of them for every Sunday at midnight. Papers like the prospectus and annotated bibliography didn't force me to do any considerable reading/research, but if I had been forced to do assignments all semester like the ones I just described, I would be so much farther along in my thesis process. I have to hold myself accountable too, of course...I could/should be farther than I am. I just think a different structure could benefit a lot of students like me (and I think there are many, from what I've gathered) who feel overwhelmed by such a huge project and struggle to hold themselves accountable. I think the idea is that we are seniors and should be able to handle this project mostly on our own. But the reality is that we are burnt out, just trying to finish college, and the thesis is so daunting. We are not too old to have some structure imposed on us.

If the existing structure doesn't change, a word of advice for other students: Don't meet the bare minimum requirements like I did, just because you can get away with it. Try to push yourself to set your own deadlines for reading every week.

Strengths: There are few requirements and you have significant independence. You have an amazing opportunity to do real history research, working with primary sources and driving your own narrative, with the guidance of your advisor. Weakness: There are few requirements and you have significant independence. It is important to hold yourself accountable; to meet with your advisor, other experts, and librarians regularly; and to exceed the basic requirements of the course, so as to set yourself up well for the second semester.
It couldn't be improved!

This course is required for history majors, so its strengths are that it helps history majors write long pieces of independent research outside the normal class structure. I don't see much room for improvement because this project is so central to the history major's experience. Another strength is that it teaches students to structure their own time with their adviser.
More regular emails or communication would help

I enjoyed the group advising format that my adviser used, because it allowed all students in the group to learn from each other and encounter different research trajectories from their own. I wish that I had received more consistent feedback on the small writing assignments that we were given over the course of the semester.

I think it would be helpful to receive more information about deadlines. This class was helpful in that I did not have to attend sections or anything, but I would have appreciated more emails that told us about upcoming deadlines. I understand students are responsible for following the syllabus and should be aware of upcoming assignments, but I am also taking several other classes with other outside expectations during a global pandemic. I felt like I was struggling to keep up and I think clearer communication would be beneficial for me and my advisor. 

I think the class was helpful for moving the draft deadline back into mid-December. It is extremely during this moment to complete work, even if I want to, and that deadline helped me allocate time to work on my draft.

Because this course didn't have weekly meetings, it depends on your advisor. My advisor has been helpful and readily available to meet and support me. I think balancing working on my thesis with other classes was challenging at times though.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I think it was nice to be able to have phone calls because I could ask any questions that came up
N/A
Professor Freeman was excellent all-around
None
I don't see any room for improvement. Professor Gitlin is wonderful.

The fact that the library was open was enormously helpful. Kudos to the library staff for doing their part to keep resources available for those in and out of New Haven. Other than that, meeting with my adviser over Zoom was slightly less enjoyable than in person but not detrimental to the project.
No real change other than no ability to do archival work
I don't think that this course was significantly impacted by COVID-19. We were able to hold group discussions just as effectively over Zoom as I believe we would have been able to do in person.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: All history students write a thesis
This course is required for senior history majors completing the year-long senior essay.
It's the thesis, so yeah
Yes, highly recommend. You will have to do it as a History major anyway, but it is a very fulfilling experience.
It is required
Yes

Yes: If you are a senior history major I would strongly recommend taking this course along with HIST 496. You can explore your chosen topic more thoroughly. I can't imagine doing my essay in one term.
Yes!
I would recommend that seniors do the two-term essay because it allows them to get more passionate about their projects and produces better scholarship.
I think the two-semester senior essay is a great way to finish off one's Yale career, by undertaking a significant research assignment and having a lengthy paper to sum up all of your work.
Its a requirement so theres no real need
Yes; I feel much more confident as a reader, writer, and researcher after completing this semester of the Senior Essay.
Yes, it is a great introduction to the senior essay process in history.
Yes, required if you're doing a two-term history senior essay.
